paperTitle: Enhancing the Merger Simulation Toolkit with ML/AI

candidates.title: Identification in Differentiated Products Markets Using Market Level Data

candidates.title: Fixed-Point Approaches to Computing Bertrand-Nash Equilibrium Prices Under Mixed-Logit Demand
candidates.contexts: For the standard merger simulation toolkit, we rely on a contraction mapping from [Morrow and Skerlos, 2011].
candidates.reason: Provides the computational backbone for the standard merger-simulation baseline used for comparison and benchmarking against the proposed ML/AI method.

candidates.title: Best practices for differentiated products demand estimation with PyBLP
candidates.contexts: Data Generation: We simulate data using the pyblp framework from [Conlon and Gortmaker, 2020] for ğ‘‡ = 100, 1 , 000, and 10 , 000 markets.
candidates.reason: Operationally important for Monte Carlo data generation and for implementing standard demand systems used in simulations and baselines.

candidates.title: Automobile Prices in Market Equilibrium
candidates.contexts: Following [Berry et al., 1995], we include the average rival distance, the average number of markets a rival serves, and the number of rival carriers. | The identifying assumption for demand is that the moment condition E [ ğœ‰ ğ‘—ğ‘¡ ğ‘§ ğ·ğ‘—ğ‘¡ ] = 0 holds for a vector of demand instruments ğ‘§ ğ·ğ‘—ğ‘¡ . | In the IO literature, a lot of effort has been devoted to estimating flexible models of demand [e.g., Berry et al., 1995] that can then be used as input in merger simulation. | Given the structure of utility and distributional assumptions, market shares ğ‘  ğ‘—ğ‘¡ are a function of observables, unobservables, and parameters in the standard form from [Berry et al., 1995].
candidates.reason: Canonical demand framework underpinning the demand side used in merger simulations and in data generation; helpful but replaceable by other demand systems.

candidates.title: Mergers with differentiated products: the case of the ready-to-eat cereal industry
candidates.contexts: The standard merger simulation methodology, developed through seminal contributions [Nevo, 2000, Werden and Froeb, 1994], relies on estimating demand elasticities and modeling firm conduct under specific assumptions about competitive behavior.
candidates.reason: Seminal application anchoring the standard merger simulation toolkit the paper seeks to enhance; central for positioning and baseline comparisons.

candidates.title: The Effects of Mergers in Differentiated Products Industries: Logit Demand and Merger Policy
candidates.contexts: The standard merger simulation toolkit, developed building on the seminal contributions of [Berry and Pakes, 1993, Hausman et al., 1994, Werden and Froeb, 1994], is based on a demand system and an assumed model of conduct. | The standard merger simulation methodology, developed through seminal contributions [Nevo, 2000, Werden and Froeb, 1994], relies on estimating demand elasticities and modeling firm conduct under specific assumptions about competitive behavior. | In the context of merger review, demand elasticities may be recovered or calibrated from data on diversion, or estimated from simple demand systems [e.g., logit as in Werden and Froeb, 1994].
candidates.reason: Canonical references for the standard merger-simulation paradigm that the paper evaluates and extends with a flexible, data-driven supply-side approach.

candidates.title: Evaluating the Performance of Merger Simulation: Evidence from the U.S. Airline Industry*
candidates.contexts: For instance, [Peters, 2006] suggests that alternative assumptions on conduct may lead to more reliable conclusions in his setting of airline mergers. | The retrospective studies of large mergers have had mixed results [Peters, 2006], potentially linked to non-Bertrand conduct [see, e.g., Ciliberto and Williams, 2014, for evidence of non-competitive conduct]. | A key limitation identified in the literature is that the restrictive assumptions about firm conduct may not adequately capture the complexity of real-world competitive interactions [see e.g., Peters, 2006]. | We evaluate the retrospective unilateral price effects of major airline mergers following previous studies of this industry (e.g., [Peters, 2006]) and other reduced-form investigations of the price effect of mergers (e.g., [Ashenfelter et al., 2013]) by creating control groups of markets notâ€¦ | As in [Peters, 2006], we define overlap markets as those in which both merging airlines operate flights for the four quarters before the merger. | Within this framework, reliance on the strong assumptions on conduct and cost, such as Bertrand-Nash pricing and constant marginal cost, may have important consequences for prediction.
candidates.reason: Shapes the empirical design and motivation in the airline application, highlighting conduct misspecification risks that the proposed method aims to address.

candidates.title: Deep learning for individual heterogeneity: an automatic inference framework
candidates.contexts: [Farrell et al., 2020] provide a theoretical foundation for using deep learning in two-stage econometric procedures, allowing for rich heterogeneity while maintaining model interpretability.
candidates.reason: Supports the use of ML within an econometric two-stage framework, aligning with the paperâ€™s ML-based estimation of structural objects.

candidates.reason: Provides standard inversion logic and demand-system background used in constructing demand inputs for merger simulation; useful but not unique.

candidates.title: Does Multimarket Contact Facilitate Tacit Collusion? Inference on Conduct Parameters in the Airline Industry
candidates.contexts: The retrospective studies of large mergers have had mixed results [Peters, 2006], potentially linked to non-Bertrand conduct [see, e.g., Ciliberto and Williams, 2014, for evidence of non-competitive conduct].
candidates.reason: Motivates flexible conduct modeling by documenting non-competitive conduct in airlines; supports the paperâ€™s case for relaxing standard conduct assumptions.

candidates.title: Market counterfactuals and the specification of multiproduct demand: A nonparametric approach
candidates.contexts: This is in the spirit of the micro-founded economic restrictions that are imposed on nonparametric demand systems in [Compiani, 2022]. | Similarly to [Compiani, 2022], who develops a method to estimate demand nonparametrically, our paper proposes a method for nonparametric estimation of the supply side.
candidates.reason: Conceptually aligns with the paperâ€™s nonparametric ethos and provides a parallel on the demand side; helpful for positioning but not essential.

candidates.title: Airline Hubs: Costs, Markups and the Implications of Customer Heterogeneity
candidates.contexts: The airline industry has received substantial attention from the IO literature [starting with Berry, 1992, Berry et al., 2006] given the rich available data and significant consolidation over the last two decades.
candidates.reason: Background on airline IO and market structure; useful for context but not needed for the paperâ€™s method.

candidates.title: Estimation of a Model of Entry in the Airline Industry
candidates.contexts: The airline industry has received substantial attention from the IO literature [starting with Berry, 1992, Berry et al., 2006] given the rich available data and significant consolidation over the last two decades.
candidates.reason: Provides broad airline IO background; not directly used in the proposed estimation or identification.

candidates.contexts: [Benkard et al., 2010] and [Bruegge et al., 2024] develop methods based on policy functions.

candidates.title: Anticompetitive Effects of Common Ownership
candidates.contexts: Following [Azar et al., 2018] and [Kennedy et al., 2017], a market is defined as a pair of cities, regardless of the flight direction.

candidates.title: The Competitive Effects of Common Ownership: Economic Foundations and Empirical Evidence
candidates.contexts: Following [Azar et al., 2018] and [Kennedy et al., 2017], a market is defined as a pair of cities, regardless of the flight direction.

candidates.title: Some Applications and Limitations of Recent Advances in Empirical Industrial Organization: Merger Analysis
candidates.contexts: The standard merger simulation toolkit, developed building on the seminal contributions of [Berry and Pakes, 1993, Hausman et al., 1994, Werden and Froeb, 1994], is based on a demand system and an assumed model of conduct.

candidates.title: Monotonic Networks
candidates.contexts: The last two approaches are related to the rich computer science literature on monotonic neural networks, starting with [Sill, 1997].
candidates.reason: Cited as part of related approaches to enforce monotonicity; not used as a core component of the estimation.

candidates.title: Unconstrained Monotonic Neural Networks
candidates.contexts: A second approach, detailed in [Wehenkel and Louppe, 2019], uses the architecture of the neural network to enforce a constant sign of the derivative of the approximated function without imposing additional constraints.
candidates.reason: Related-methods citation on monotonicity constraints in neural nets; not essential to the paperâ€™s main results.

candidates.title: Deep Lattice Networks and Partial Monotonic Functions
candidates.contexts: The first approach enforces constraints on weights and activation functions in particular neural network layers, e.g., [You et al., 2017].
candidates.reason: Alternative approach for monotonic function approximation; included as related background.

candidates.title: An Adversarial Approach to Structural Estimation
candidates.contexts: [Kaji et al., 2023] introduce â€œadversarial estimation,â€ which formulates the estimator as a minimax problem between a generator and discriminator, achieving parametric efficiency under correct specification.
candidates.reason: Related minimax/adversarial estimation literature; not directly implemented in the proposed method.

candidates.title: Adversarial Generalized Method of Moments

candidates.title: Provably Efficient Neural Estimation of Structural Equation Model: An Adversarial Approach
candidates.contexts: Several studies, including those by [Dikkala et al., 2020, Lewis and Syrgkanis, 2018, Liao et al., 2020], and [Zhang et al., 2023] have advanced this literature.

candidates.title: Minimax Estimation of Conditional Moment Models
candidates.contexts: Several studies, including those by [Dikkala et al., 2020, Lewis and Syrgkanis, 2018, Liao et al., 2020], and [Zhang et al., 2023] have advanced this literature.
